Let‚Äôs recommit to the critical work that remains in delivering true freedom, equality and justice to Black Americans here in Vermont and across our nation. (6/6)

Today, I invite Vermonters to join me and communities across the state in a moment of meaningful reflection, recognition and commemoration of this day ‚Äì how far we‚Äôve come, and how incredibly far we have to go. (5/6)
Reversing these systemic inequities continues to require deep, consistent and proactive work across all sectors, at all levels, and at every level of government. (4/6)

From healthcare to education to transportation to housing and much more, deep, systemic inequities still exist. Centuries of slavery left deep scars on our nation, a culture of both overt and covert racism, and systems that have, for too long, served to perpetuate division. (3/6)

We commemorate the emancipation of enslaved men, women and children, but recognize that a century and a half later, true freedom, justice and equality are still not fully realized for Black Americans in this country. (2/6)
Today, as a nation, we commemorate Juneteenth. On this day 157 years ago, the last enslaved Americans, in Galveston, Texas, were ordered free under the Emancipation Proclamation. (1/6)

The invaluable work by the Committee gives me hope. Through this bipartisan work to reveal what happened that day, we can hold our elected officials accountable and preserve the rule of law.

Our democracy is hurt, but it‚Äôs not broken. We will come out stronger on the other side.

As we hold those responsible for Jan 6 accountable, we must also face the reality that domestic terrorists & white suprematists have a real presence in our country ‚Äî the Proud Boys were there on Jan 6 & white supremacist ideology was responsible for the recent murders in Buffalo.

Former President Trump is directly responsible for what happened that day. He assembled the mob and ordered the attack.

Let me be clear: no one is above the law ‚Äî even former Presidents.

@dallas_hawthorn As a former Assistant Attorney General, I understand the important role that our criminal justice system plays in protecting our trans community members. We must also address hate crimes and combat the rising national tide of violent extremism we‚Äôve seen across our country.

@dallas_hawthorn In Congress, I‚Äôll work to pass the Equality Act to make sex, sexual orientation, and gender identity a protected class. We must also expand The Affordable Care Act to add gender-affirming care as an essential health benefit.

@dallas_hawthorn Supporting trans youth and adults is important to me. Here in Vermont, I‚Äôm proud of the steps we‚Äôve taken to become a legal refuge for trans youth, joining 18 other states that have done the same. But, we must act on a federal level as well.

It‚Äôs time, past time, to put politics aside and save lives‚Äîfor Emma and Eliza, for all students, for our teachers, for our humanity, CONGRESS MUST ACT!

57 years later, reproductive liberty is still under attack. 

If Roe falls, it‚Äôs likely that access to contraceptives is next. Conservative Justices are chipping away at established rights. In Congress, I‚Äôll fight to protect safe & accessible reproductive healthcare.

#VTPoli https://t.co/7bVttz3Ufo

And l know I‚Äôm not alone in this battle; too many Vermonters face these same decisions. In Congress, I will fight for universal paid leave so no Vermonter is forced to choose between a paycheck and caring for someone they love.

This fight is personal to me. When my mother was struggling with MS, I used my vacation days and sick leave to care for her. But as days turned to weeks, my paid time off ran out. I wondered how I would afford rent and student loan payments. https://t.co/SLdSDVDl4k
